div.l: For euꝰery clerk anone helde wtith other
He seide the man was woode my leef brother
And euꝰery wyght gan laughen of þis stryf
Thus swyved was the Carpenters wyf
For all his kepyng and his ielousye
And Absolon hath kyst hir nether yee
And Nicholas is scalded in the tout
This tale is done and god save all þe rout
Thus endeth the Millers tale
and begynneth þe ꝓprologe of þe Reve
Whan folk han̄ laughen̄ / at this nyce cas
Of Absolon̄ and hend Nicholas
Diủers folk diuersly they seid
But for the more ꝑpart they lough and pleid
Ne at this tale I sawe no man hym greve
But it were onely Oswold the Reve
By cause he was of Carpenters craft
A litle yre is in his hert laft
He ganne to grucch and blamed it a light
Sytheke koth he full wele I shall þe quyte
Wᵗith bleryng of a proude myllers yie
Yf þat me list speke of rybawdye
But yk am old · me list nat pleye for age
Gras tyme is gon̄ my foder is now forage
This white top̄pe / writeth myn̄ old yeres
Myn̄ hert is also mouled as myn̄ heres
But yit I fare / as doth an Openars
That ylk fruyt is ever lenger þe wers
Till it be roton̄ in mullok or in stree
We old men I drede so faren̄ we
Tyll we be roten̄ / kan̄ we nat be rype
We hoppe all wey while that the world woll pipe
For in our͗e wille / ther͗e stiketh eủere a naill
To have an hore here / and a grene taill
As hath a leek / for though our͗e myght be gon̄
Our͗e will desireth folye / ever͗e in one
For whan we may nought doon̄ / þan woll we speke
Yitte in oure asshen old / is fire yreke
· iiij · gledes han̄ we / which I shall devise
Auᵃauntyng / lying / angre Couetise
